title: 106_s1468
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Capitol building in Washington, D.C. is a symbol of democracy, with millions of visitors annually lacking proper facilities. Security is provided by the Capitol Police, and funds have been allocated for a Visitor Center to enhance the visitor experience. Coins are authorized to commemorate this initiative. Congress aims to enhance security and visitor experience at the Capitol by allowing voluntary fundraising for the Capitol Visitor Center. Coins commemorating the first Congress meeting in the Capitol will help fund the construction and maintenance of the Visitor Center. Coins commemorating the first Congress meeting in the Capitol will help fund the construction and maintenance of the Visitor Center. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue various coins, including bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins. If bimetallic coins are not feasible, $5 gold coins may be minted instead. The Secretary of the Treasury may mint and issue $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, containing 90% gold and 10% alloy. These coins shall be legal tender and may have mintage levels waived as per the specified regulations. The Secretary obtains platinum and gold for minting coins from available sources, and may obtain silver from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of coins is specified in the Act. Design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the Capitol Building. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year "2000", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Capitol Preservation Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, minted at a single facility, and will bear the year "2000" inscription. The Secretary will consult with the Commission for promotion and marketing. SEC. 7 of the Act outlines the sale of coins, including pricing, bulk sales, and prepaid orders. The sale price includes face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. Surcharges for coins are specified by the Secretary. SEC. 8 of the Act states that all surcharges from coin sales will be deposited in the Capitol Preservation Fund to aid in the construction and maintenance of a Capitol Visitor Center.
